questions.text: Due to the bleeding, the surgeon ligated (tied off) the suprascapular artery as it crossed the top of the scapula. There was no concern however, as she knew that direct collateral branches of which artery would supply the normal distribution of the suprascapular artery.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Direct collateral branches of the scapular circumflex artery would supply the normal distribution of the suprascapular artery.

  • The suprascapular artery supplies the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles.

Scapular Anastomosis Includes:

  • Suprascapular artery (from thyrocervical trunk)
  • Scapular circumflex artery (from subscapular artery)
  • Dorsal scapular artery (from subclavian)

So, if one of these arteries needs to be ligated, the other ones will supply the scapula.

Explanation for other options:

The anterior and posterior circumflex humeral arteries anastomose with each other, but they do not contribute to the blood supply of the scapula. (Option A and B)

The thoracodorsal artery is another branch of the subscapular artery (just like the scapular circumflex artery), which supplies the latissimus dorsi. (Option D)

questions.text: In a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus, which artery may be injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior humeral circumflex might get injured in a surgical neck of the humerus fracture.

  • Surgical Neck Fracture may injure:
    • Axillary nerve
    • Posterior and anterior circumflex humeral arteries
  • Axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery pass through the quadrangular space

Explanation for other options:

Subscapular artery (Option A): Higher up, it gives off branches to the scapular region and is not closely related to the surgical neck.

Radial recurrent artery (Option C): Found near the elbow, unrelated to humerus fractures at the neck.

Circumflex scapular artery (Option D): Found in the scapular region, not near the surgical neck of the humerus.

questions.text: If the second part of the axillary artery was interrupted, collateral blood flow could pass from branches of the thyrocervical trunk into which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of blockage in the second part of the axillary artery, blood can bypass the blockage through the anastomosis via the circumflex scapular artery.

The suprascapular artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk (from the subclavian artery).

It forms an anastomosis with:

  • Dorsal scapular artery (from subclavian)
  • Circumflex scapular artery (from subscapular artery)

The circumflex scapular artery is a branch of the subscapular artery, which comes from the third part of the axillary artery.

  • In case of blockage in the second part of the axillary artery, blood can flow:

→From the suprascapular artery

→through the scapular anastomosis

→into the circumflex scapular artery

→retrograde into the subscapular artery

→reaches the third part of the axillary artery.

  • This pathway bypasses the second part of the axillary artery.

Explanation for other options:

Anterior & posterior humeral circumflex arteries (Option A and D): Both from the third part of the axillary artery; they anastomose locally, not bypassing.

Deep brachial artery (Option C): A Branch of the brachial artery in the arm with no role in scapular anastomosis.

Thoracoacromial artery: A Branch of the second part of the axillary artery, it is not involved in bypass.

choices.text: The axillary vein lies anterior and inferior to the axillary artery.
The cords of the brachial plexus are named based on their position relative to the axillary artery.
The axillary artery becomes the brachial artery at the lower border of the teres major.
The axillary sheath encloses only the axillary artery and vein.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the anatomical relationships within the axilla is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The axillary sheath is a fibrous sheath of connective tissue that surrounds the neurovascular bundle in the axilla (armpit). It encloses the axillary artery, axillary vein, and the brachial plexus, specifically the three cords of the brachial plexus.

  • The axillary vein is anterior and inferior to the artery. (Option A)
  • The lateral, posterior, and medial cords of the brachial plexus are named relative to the axillary artery. (Option B)
  • The axillary artery becomes the brachial artery at the lower border of the teres major. (Option C)

choices.text: Lateral wall - formed by intertubercular groove of the humerus.
Medial wall - consists of the serratus anterior and the thoracic wall (ribs and intercostal muscles).
Posterior wall - formed by the subscapularis, teres major and latissimus dorsi
Anterior wall - contains the serratus anterior and the subclavius muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the boundary of axilla ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The anterior wall is formed mainly by pectoralis major and pectoralis minor, not the coracobrachialis.

Boundaries of the axilla

Apex - also known as the axillary inlet, it is formed by the lateral border of the first rib, the superior border of the scapula, and the posterior border of the clavicle.

  • Lateral wall - formed by the intertubercular groove of the humerus.
  • Medial wall - consists of the serratus anterior and the thoracic wall (ribs and intercostal muscles).
  • Anterior wall - contains the pectoralis major and the underlying pectoralis minor, and the subclavius muscles.
  • Posterior wall - formed by the subscapularis, teres major and latissimus dorsi.
